headline.main: Times Photographer Complains of Israeli Soldiers' 'Cruelty' at Border Crossing

docs.abstract: Israel's Defense Ministry apologized on Monday for forcing a pregnant New York Times photographer to remove her clothes and submit to a physical search after she had already passed through an X-ray machine three times at a checkpoint in Gaza last month.

docs.abstract: Eviction deadlines were allowed to pass with little change for Occupy protests in Los Angeles and Philadelphia, and some Occupy Wall Street drummers will play on an Occupy benefit album.
docs.snippet: Eviction deadlines were allowed to pass with little change for Occupy protests in Los Angeles and Philadelphia, and some Occupy Wall Street drummers will play on an Occupy benefit album.

docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps slower to act after all that turkey, city officials allowed Monday morning eviction deadlines to pass with little change for Occupy protests in Los Angeles and Philadelphia. The Los Angeles police said they were focused on clearing streets for the morning commute and arrested four protesters for blocking traffic. In Philadelphia, protesters who held an eviction party Sunday night were still waiting for things to change early Monday afternoon. Nine people were arrested in Augusta, Maine, for demonstrating at the governor's mansion after their encampment was closed. [New York Times, Portland Press-Herald]

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House should not wobble on requiring free contraceptive coverage in health insurance plans.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges the White House to resist calls from Roman Catholic and other religious leaders to alter new rules that include contraceptives for women in the package of preventive health care services that all insurers must cover without a deductible or co-payment beginning in 2012; holds that plan will drive down rates of unintended pregnancy and abortion.
docs.snippet: The White House should not wobble on requiring free contraceptive coverage in health insurance plans.

docs.lead_paragraph: A district attorney was forced to drop all felony charges in a case against Planned Parenthood, but an investigation into document destruction is under way.

headline.seo: Passions Stay High in Kansas Planned Parenthood Case
headline.main: Abortion Case Loses Ground, but Issue Stays Hot in Kansas
headline.print_headline: Abortion Case Loses Ground, But Issue Stays Hot in Kansas

docs.abstract: Kansas prosecutors announce that they have dropped all the felony charges against an Overland Park Planned Parenthood affiliate after years of legal battling, citing faulty record keeping; the case has been treated locally as something of a proxy in the battle over abortion rights, and the surprise announcement by prosecutors has intensified local interest in the issue.
docs.snippet: A district attorney was forced to drop all felony charges in a case against Planned Parenthood, but an investigation into document destruction is under way.
